Expectation1: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation1: A congregant has just passed away and the family needs him to officiate the funeral service very soon.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: I was sitting in my study, reviewing notes for tomorrow’s Torah class, when my phone rang. It was Miriam, her voice trembling. Her father had just passed away, and the family needed me to officiate the funeral—today, if possible. I promised I’d be there, feeling the weight of their grief settle on my shoulders. As I hung up, my other phone buzzed. It was a legislative aide from Senator Klein’s office. “Rabbi, I have ten minutes right now to discuss the bill you’ve been championing. Can you talk?” My heart pounded. This was the moment I’d been waiting for—months of organizing, rallying, and writing op-eds had led to this chance. But Miriam’s family was waiting for me to guide them through their loss. I stared at both phones, feeling the expectations of my congregation and my cause pressing in from both sides. My hands shook as I tried to decide which call to answer first, torn between comforting the bereaved and seizing a fleeting opportunity to make real change.
